channel.title: Comments on: Using ClusterJ (part of MySQL Cluster Connector for Java) – a tutorial
channel.description: Database technologies - especially around scalability and High Availability

item.title: By: marcos
item.dc:creator: marcos
item.description: ClusterJ needs at least Java 5? Can not run on 1.4?
item.content:encoded: ClusterJ needs at least Java 5? Can not run on 1.4?

item.title: By: andrew
item.dc:creator: andrew
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/mysql-cluster/using-clusterj-part-of-mysql-cluster-connector-for-java-a-tutorial#comment-17066">Salman</a>.
Hi Salman,
you could start here... <a href="http://dev.mysql.com/doc/ndbapi/en/mccj-clusterj-transaction.html#mccj-clusterj-transaction-begin" title="Transactions with MySQL Cluster ClusterJ" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://dev.mysql.com/doc/ndbapi/en/mccj-clusterj-transaction.html#mccj-clusterj-transaction-begin</a>
Andrew.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Salman.

Hi Salman,

you could start here… http://dev.mysql.com/doc/ndbapi/en/mccj-clusterj-transaction.html#mccj-clusterj-transaction-begin

Andrew.

item.title: By: Salman
item.dc:creator: Salman
item.description:
Hey,
How can we batch multiple read operation in a transaction? Any code snippet would be great
/Salman
item.content:encoded:
Hey,

How can we batch multiple read operation in a transaction? Any code snippet would be great

/Salman

item.title: By: andrew
item.dc:creator: andrew
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/mysql-cluster/using-clusterj-part-of-mysql-cluster-connector-for-java-a-tutorial#comment-390">Afzal</a>.
Afzal, not sure what you're asking. Is the create table command failing?
Andrew.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Afzal.

Afzal, not sure what you’re asking. Is the create table command failing?

Andrew.

item.title: By: Afzal
item.dc:creator: Afzal
item.description: how can i do this? [billy@ws1 ~]$ mysql -u root -h 127.0.0.1 -P 3306 -u root mysql> create database clusterdb;use clusterdb; mysql> CREATE TABLE employee ( -> id INT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY, -> first VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL, -> last VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL, -> municipality VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL, -> started VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL, -> ended VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL, -> department INT NOT NULL DEFAULT 1, -> UNIQUE KEY idx_u_hash (first,last) USING HASH, -> KEY idx_municipality (municipality) -> ) ENGINE=NDBCLUSTER;
item.content:encoded:
how can i do this?
[billy@ws1 ~]$ mysql -u root -h 127.0.0.1 -P 3306 -u root
mysql> create database clusterdb;use clusterdb;
mysql> CREATE TABLE employee (
-> id INT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY,
-> first VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL,
-> last VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL,
-> municipality VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL,
-> started VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL,
-> ended VARCHAR(64) DEFAULT NULL,
-> department INT NOT NULL DEFAULT 1,
-> UNIQUE KEY idx_u_hash (first,last) USING HASH,
-> KEY idx_municipality (municipality)
-> ) ENGINE=NDBCLUSTER;

item.title: By: Tousif Khan
item.dc:creator: Tousif Khan
item.description: Excellent Tutorial. its really very helpful. Thanks Andrew.
item.content:encoded:
Excellent Tutorial. its really very helpful.
Thanks Andrew.
